qas.question: What was required for quality playback of DBX recordings?
How compatible were DBX encoded recordings with prior technologies?
What was the intention of DBX encoded recordings?

answers.text: reduced the effect of surface noise on quiet passages

qas.question: What did CBS develop in order to reduce outside noise?

context: The <a1_0>mid-1970s<a1_0/> saw the introduction of dbx-encoded records, again for the audiophile niche market. These were <a2_0>completely incompatible with<a2_0/> standard record playback preamplifiers, relying on the dbx compandor encoding/decoding scheme to greatly increase dynamic range (dbx encoded disks were recorded with the dynamic range compressed by a factor of two in dB: quiet sounds were meant to be played back at low gain and loud sounds were meant to be played back at high gain, via <a0_0>automatic gain control<a0_0/> in the playback equipment; this <a3_0>reduced the effect of surface noise on quiet passages<a3_0/>). A similar and very short-lived scheme involved using the CBS-developed <a4_0>"CX" noise reduction<a4_0/> encoding/decoding scheme.
